pr_title: Add data compression property to SQL Server tables

timeline.message: Add data compression property to SQL Server tables

timeline.author: findepi
findepi
findepi
findepi
findepi

timeline.bodyText:
This is correct because currently SQL Server does not seem to support enabling table compression by default for a schema or database. However, they can add in the future.
Therefore today NONE is a good default, but can become a wrong choice without a code change on our part.
Let's replace NONE with UNSET (or DEFAULT). Then do not add WITH (DATA_COMPRESSION clause when compression is the UNSET.
cc @kokosing
timeline.author: findepi

replies.bodyText:
Correct me if I am wrong, NONE means no compression.

Let's replace NONE with UNSET (or DEFAULT). Then do not add WITH (DATA_COMPRESSION clause when compression is the UNSET.

Let's implement UNSET by not setting property value, so let's make it nullable and when it is null we should just use sql server system default behaviour.
replies.author: kokosing

replies.bodyText: But when we run SHOW CREATE TABLE for any table from SQLServer we won't be able to capture the UNSET/DEFAULT rather we get only NONE. How can we handle in that situation ?
replies.author: Praveen2112

timeline.bodyText:
This is not safe. Should SQL Server add new compression mode (say, "BLOCK"), we don't want to fail the method here. I'd rather return no property.
also, is there a test ensuring SHOW CREATE TABLE doesn't return unnecessary data_compression property for all tables now?
timeline.author: findepi

replies.bodyText:
is there a test ensuring SHOW CREATE TABLE doesn't return unnecessary data_compression property for all tables now

That property will now be added. I think we should skip it when it is value is unknown (null), when it differs among paritions.
replies.author: kokosing

timeline.bodyText:
what if we get two rows? validate & fail in such a case, this means our query is wrong
verify(!resultSet.next(), "Unexpected second result row");
timeline.author: findepi

timeline.bodyText:
As you explained to me offline, the SQL Server treats table with single partition as an unpartitioned table.
Is there a guarantee that the only partition will have partition_number=1?
Also, in case of a partitioned table, we should not return compression info from the first partition.
timeline.author: findepi

replies.bodyText:
From their documentation it looks like they set partition_number as 1 for non-partitioned tables.
Ref : https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/relational-databases/system-catalog-views/sys-partitions-transact-sql?view=sql-server-ver15
replies.author: Praveen2112

replies.bodyText: From their docs it looks like 1 is used only for non-partitioned tables
replies.author: Praveen2112

timeline.bodyText: Wonder why we need to specify the default twice -- above and here.
timeline.author: findepi

timeline.bodyText: nit: i'd put this below the test method, but up to you
timeline.author: findepi

timeline.bodyText: you might want to replace multiple subsequent white characters in to a single space, then value of createQuery would be easier to maintain.
timeline.author: kokosing
kokosing

replies.bodyText: But for using JDBI we might need inject a ConnectionProvider but for fetching a connection we need to JdbcIdentity
replies.author: Praveen2112

replies.bodyText: i didn't quite get it. Anyway, you can attach jdbi to an existing connector.
replies.author: findepi
